slides.title: Sometimes, we are unsure if a claim should be paid or STS SH 4
slides.ocrText:
Sometimes, we are unsure if a claim should be paid or STS SH 4
not. Several conditions need to be verified before a claim
is paid. For example, the claim must be for a covered
loss and the event must have occurred when the policy
was in force. There are also some data completion
requirements that affect the payment of a claim.

We need ClaimCenter to manage these requirement
automatically to reduce the risk of overpayments.

slides.title: Constraining claim costs payments fa
slides.originalNotes:
Constraining claim costs payments
In ClaimCenter, there are two ways to constrain, or restrict, payments; maturity levels and financial holds. Maturity levels prevent all payments both claim costs and claim expenses. Maturity levels are data-driven which means there are conditions set on the completeness of data that the claim and exposures must meet before they are moved to the ability to pay level. For example, there could be a condition that restricts ability to pay on an exposure until the driver's license of the payee is recorded.
There are also some business based conditions that affect payments. If a insurer is unsure that the claim is for a covered event, then they would not want to pay claim costs. The same would be true if they were unsure that the event occurred while the policy was in force or if they could not verify the policy. Any of those business conditions should prevent claim costs being paid, but not claim expenses. This type of restriction is covered by financial holds.

| Constraining claim costs payments fa

• Maturity level (review)
+ Claims and exposures must be at ability to pay before any payments are made
+ Maturity levels can prevent all payments (costs and expenses)

+ Maturity levels are data driven; all required data must be valid to move forward to ability to pay

• Business based conditions that affect payment
+ The insurer is unsure that the claim is for a covered event
* The insurer is unsure that the policy was in force at the time of the event
+ The insured is simply reporting the incident with no intention of being paid

+ The policy cannot be verified

• ClaimCenter uses financial holds functionality to allow for these conditions

slides.title: Financial holds
slides.originalNotes:
Financial holds
Financial holds differ from maturity levels in that they restrict indemnity, or cost payments, but not expense payments. Maturity levels, or ability to pay, restrict all payments. There are three financial holds conditions that are defined in the base application: Coverage in Question, Incident only, and Policy unverified. The financial hold status is not a stored value but rather is evaluated for every financial transaction. Anytime a transaction is created, it is evaluated against the current financial holds conditions.

slides.ocrText:
| Financial holds G

Financial holds mark a claim so that no indemnity (cost) payments can be made

Different than keeping a claim from reaching ability to pay
+ Financial holds allow expense payments (case management, etc.)

+ Not reaching ability to pay restricts all payments (expense and indemnity)

The base application has three defined conditions that result in financial holds
* Coverage in Question (CIQ)
* Claim Incident Only

* Claim Policy Unverified
Financial hold status is not a stored value

Financial hold conditions are evaluated for every financial transaction

slides.originalNotes:
How financial holds work (I of 3)
Every time a transaction is created, the financial holds conditions are evaluated. When any of the financial hold conditions are true, financial holds are applied. If the transaction is for an expense payment, the user is warned that financial holds are in place.

slides.title: Financial holds conditions — Coverage in Question [j
slides.originalNotes:
Financial holds conditions — Coverage in Question
Coverage in question is one of the financial hold conditions in the base application. Coverage in question means that for some reason, the insurer is not sure that there is coverage for the claim. The conditions which result in coverage in question are if the loss date is outside of the policy effective dates or if the policy has a status other than in force or archived.

Coverage in question may also be set manually for any reason. Once it is set, it may only be reset or changed by a supervisor or manager. If a claim is in the coverage in question condition, then there is an icon displayed on the claim.

slides.title: Financial holds conditions — Incident only
slides.originalNotes:
Financial holds conditions — Incident only
ClaimCenter provides a way to mark a claim as an Incident Only claim. An Incident Only claim is used to record as much information about a potential claim as possible without processing it as a claim. For example, in Workers' Comp, the employer may be required to record a Workers' Comp claim within 48 hours of the incident However, it may not be known whether there will be medical care required or if lost time may be involved. It could be a simple incident, but to make sure, the employer reports the incident regardless of the potential outcome.

Because it is an Incident Only claim, financial holds are in place. Remember that an incident only claim is under financial holds, so no indemnity (claim costs) will be paid, but claim expenses may be paid.

slides.ocrText:
| Financial holds conditions — Incident only i

• The insurer receives claim information, but it turns out not to be a claim

+ Example: Employer reports an injury, but before it is certain to become a claim
« May not be clear initially, so some expenses were incurred (medical reports)
• Financial holds allow payment of expenses but not indemnity costs

• Incident Only is a property on the Claim Status screen and the New Claim Wizard

slides.title: Financial holds conditions — Unverified policy fa
slides.originalNotes:
Financial holds conditions — Unverified policy
The third condition in Financial Holds is an unverified policy. In the normal process, ClaimCenter uses policies from an external policy system to verify coverage for a claim. The policy is copied into ClaimCenter from that external policy system when the claim is created. Policies can also be created directly in ClaimCenter

A customer service representative would create a policy only if they could not find the policy and need it to create a claim. They will see that the policy is not verified and will have to be checked before the claim is removed from financial holds. A policy is also marked as unverified if a user makes changes to the policy copied from the external policy system. All claims with unverified policies are placed under financial holds, which means that expenses may be paid against the claim, but not claim costs.
